Romero’s first entry into that particular camp called ‘Night Of The Living Dead’ spawned nine additional movies, as well as several popular theatrical sequels by other filmmakers. With popularity apparent, studios wanted in on this zombie action flick gravy train.

The Bone Snatcher is about a group miners who go on a search for a missing crew of miners in the Namib Desert. When the find them, they do not realize that what was going on with them is solely related to an unseen and ancient race: The half-African/Bantu and possible South African/American Creature-Hunter kidnaps people to vivisect, so that he can build hu-manoid beings out of their body sand create their army.

While credited as a Tom and Jerry cartoon, this is not the cat-and-mouse team but an earlier Mutt-and-Jeff rip-off featuring them going about to survive in today's turbulent economy. In the end, they channel their problems over into other aspects of their lives until they are engulfed in payback wrath by another group of stick-up victims. (The wild-eyed ones with two spoons cut up from a single one.)

Michael Dudikoff stars as Joe Armstrong a martial artist who fights ninjas who are stealing weapons from the U.S Army, in this entertaining yet admittedly brainless comedic action film. This film is clearly an attempt to catch the wave of martial arts popularity ; It borrows many characteristics and themes from Asian and American cinema alike, while substituting thick, delicious Texan accents with those of epileptic convulsions.
